physDesc.p: This homily has a very large number of corrections and additions, many of which are very brief. Because of the visual similarities between the two correcting hands, as well as similarity between these hands and other correcting hands elsewhere in the manuscript, many of these small interventions have been marked uncertain. There are also some areas of very dark overwriting of the main text that remain uncertain but seem to be the work of a single hand on pp. 375-6. Similar changes appear in an earlier homily, e.g. on p. 341, 'gyrode' and an abbreviated '-orum'.

handNote.p: Main hand: late square minuscule, occasional raising of e; makes self corrections by erasing and rewriting or by superlinear addition with slim insertion mark; belly of g very dominant and often extends quite far to the left with rather smaller loop; left branch of y is usually a bit curved; belly of thorn and wynn upward-looking, while still remaining rounded, and quite compact (about half as wide as belly of p). Skilled, very regular, upright, and elegant hand.

Frequent emending hand in pale ink. Some level of lean to the right, tendency to 'climb' upward-right from the main text line when writing. Repeatedly changes 'hryrnyss' and its declined forms to forms of 'styrung' and makes changes regarding time/day on which the homily is to be read. Overall angular quality, somewhat slanty aspect. Top of a is pointed. Tail of g open, g overall very angular and boxy, with longish top stroke. Thorn usually with short ascender and descender with pointed upward looking belly. Rarely (never?) uses descending insular long s. Long/tall s in final positions often especially tall and long. Tongue of e curls up slightly; e often with a gap on top.

Less frequent emending hand in dark ink. More upright character. Top of g quite long, tail of g usually closed. Sometimes writes his own corrections over those of EC0312c. Changes and expands 'iudean' and similar to adjectival forms, e.g., 'iudeaiscan'/'iudeaiscra'.
